title: Ramen Shop
description: You walk into a busy ramen shop in Tokyo. You'll navigate the ticket machine, customize your order, and make it through your first real ramen shop experience.
cultural_notes: Many ramen shops use a ticket vending machine (é£Ÿåˆ¸æ©Ÿ shokken-ki) at the entrance. You buy a ticket before you sit down.
Staff almost always greet loudly with ã„ã‚‰ã£ã—ã‚ƒã„ã¾ã› when you enter. You don't need to reply â€” a nod or small bow is totally fine.
Common customizations: noodle firmness (å›ºã‚ katame / ãµã¤ã† futsuu / ã‚„ã‚ã‚‰ã‹ã‚ yawarakame), soup richness (ã“ã£ã¦ã‚Š kotteri / ã‚ã£ã•ã‚Š assari).
When you finish eating, saying ã”ã¡ãã†ã•ã¾ã§ã—ãŸ (gochisousama deshita) is common and appreciated.

enter_1.speaker: staff
enter_1.cultural_note: You don't need to reply to this. A nod or small bow is totally natural.

seat_type_1.speaker: staff
seat_type_1.romaji: Kauntaa aitemasu. Shokken saki ni onegai shimasu.
seat_type_1.en: The counter is open. Please buy a ticket first.
seat_type_1.cultural_note: Head to the vending machine on your right. Pick your ramen, pay, and bring the ticket to your seat.

seat_type_2.speaker: staff
seat_type_2.romaji: Sukoshi nara daijoubu desu. Saki ni kochira de shokken onegai shimasu.
seat_type_2.en: A little English is okay. First, please get a meal ticket here.

ticket_guide_2.speaker: customer
ticket_guide_2.romaji: Sumimasen, hajimete deâ€¦ dousureba ii desu ka?
ticket_guide_2.en: Sorry, it's my first timeâ€¦ what should I do?

ticket_help_1.speaker: staff
ticket_help_1.romaji: Daijoubu desu yo. Ichiban ue ga ichiban ninki desu. Koko oshite, okane irete kudasai.
ticket_help_1.en: No worries. The top one is the most popular. Press here and put in your money.

ticket_machine_1.speaker: staff
ticket_machine_1.romaji: Kochira no shokken-ki de onegai shimasu. Ninki wa kono shouyu raamen desu.
ticket_machine_1.en: Please use this ticket machine. Our most popular is this soy-sauce ramen.

ticket_help_rec_1.speaker: staff
ticket_help_rec_1.romaji: Kochira no tokusei raamen ga ichiban detemasu ne. Aji wa koime desu.
ticket_help_rec_1.en: This special ramen sells the most. The flavor is on the richer side.

ticket_rec_decide_2.speaker: customer
ticket_rec_decide_2.romaji: Mou sukoshi assari shita no wa arimasu ka?
ticket_rec_decide_2.en: Do you have something a bit lighter?

ticket_light_1.speaker: staff
ticket_light_1.romaji: Kono shio raamen ga assari-me desu. Gaikoku no kata ni mo ninki desu yo.
ticket_light_1.en: This salt ramen is lighter. It's popular with visitors too.

ticket_spicy_1.speaker: staff
ticket_spicy_1.romaji: Hai, kono kara-miso raamen ga karame desu. Kekkou karai desu kedo daijoubu desu ka?
ticket_spicy_1.en: Yes, this spicy miso ramen is hot. It's pretty spicy â€” is that okay?

ticket_spicy_mild.speaker: customer
ticket_spicy_mild.romaji: Uun, sukoshi karai kurai ga ii desu.
ticket_spicy_mild.en: Hmm, I'd like just a little spicy.

ticket_spicy_suggest.speaker: staff
ticket_spicy_suggest.romaji: Jaa, futsuu no miso ni karasa topping sukuname ni shimashou ka.
ticket_spicy_suggest.en: Then how about regular miso with just a small spicy topping?

ticket_done_1.speaker: staff
ticket_done_1.romaji: Arigatou gozaimasu. Kauntaa aiteru no de, douzo osuki na seki e.
ticket_done_1.en: Thank you. Counter seats are open â€” please sit wherever you like.

seat_sit_1.speaker: customer
seat_sit_1.romaji: (Sit at counter and hand over ticket.) Onegai shimasu.
seat_sit_1.en: (You sit and place your ticket on the counter.) Here you go.

water_info_1.speaker: staff
water_info_1.romaji: Omizu wa oku no potto kara gojiyuu ni douzo.
water_info_1.en: Please help yourself to water from the pot in the back.
water_info_1.cultural_note: Water and sometimes condiments (sesame, pepper, soy sauce) are usually self-serve in ramen shops.

order_confirm_1.speaker: staff
order_confirm_1.romaji: Tokusei miso raamen desu ne. Men no katasa dou shimasu ka?
order_confirm_1.en: Special miso ramen. How would you like the noodles?
order_confirm_1.cultural_note: å›ºã‚ (katame) = firm, ãµã¤ã† (futsuu) = normal, ã‚„ã‚ã‚‰ã‹ã‚ (yawarakame) = soft. First-timers usually go ãµã¤ã†.

noodle_ans_3.speaker: customer
noodle_ans_3.romaji: Sumimasen, amari wakarimasen. Futsuu ga ii desu.
noodle_ans_3.en: Sorry, I'm not sure. Normal is fine.

noodle_staff_1.speaker: staff
noodle_staff_1.romaji: Jaa, futsuu de odashi shimasu ne.

noodle_staff_2.speaker: staff
noodle_staff_2.romaji: Hai, men wa futsuu de otsukuri shimasu.

garlic_q_1.speaker: staff
garlic_q_1.romaji: Ninniku irete mo daijoubu desu ka? Nigate deshitara nukimasu.
garlic_q_1.en: Is garlic okay? If you don't like it, I can leave it out.

garlic_ans_1.speaker: customer
garlic_ans_1.en: Fine by me. Please add it.

smalltalk_option_1.speaker: customer
smalltalk_option_1.en: Excuse me, do you have Wi-Fi?

smalltalk_wifi_1.speaker: staff
smalltalk_wifi_1.romaji: Sumimasen, wai-fai wa nain desu yo.

food_arrive_1.speaker: staff
food_arrive_1.romaji: Omatase shimashita~, tokusei miso raamen desu.
food_arrive_1.en: Sorry for the wait â€” here's your special miso ramen!

food_react_1.speaker: customer
food_react_1.cultural_note: ã„ãŸã ãã¾ã™ (itadakimasu) is said before eating â€” like giving thanks for the meal. Always a good move.

food_react_2.speaker: customer
food_react_2.romaji: Sumimasen, hashi mou ichizen moraemasu ka?
food_react_2.en: Excuse me, could I get another pair of chopsticks?

eating_1.speaker: staff
eating_1.romaji: Aji usukattari shitara, itte kudasai ne.
eating_1.en: If the flavor's too light or anything, just say so.

after_eat_1.speaker: customer
after_eat_1.en: (You finish eating.) Thank you for the meal.
after_eat_1.cultural_note: ã”ã¡ãã†ã•ã¾ã§ã—ãŸ is said when you finish eating. Staff genuinely appreciate hearing it.

pay_timing_1.speaker: staff
pay_timing_1.romaji: Arigatou gozaimasu. Okaikei wa shokken sono mama de daijoubu desu.
pay_timing_1.en: Thank you. The ticket covers payment â€” you're all set.

extra_order_staff_1.speaker: staff
extra_order_staff_1.romaji: Hai, kaedama arimasu. Genkin de hyaku gojuu en desu.
extra_order_staff_1.en: Yes, we have kaedama. It's 150 yen cash.
extra_order_staff_1.cultural_note: æ›¿ãˆç‰ (kaedama) is an extra serving of noodles added to your remaining broth. Very common in tonkotsu and miso shops.

extra_order_decide_2.speaker: customer
extra_order_decide_2.romaji: Yappari daijoubu desu. Mou onaka ippai desu.
extra_order_decide_2.en: Actually I'm okay. I'm already full.

leave_1.speaker: customer
leave_1.en: Thank you, it was really good.

leave_staff_1.speaker: staff
leave_staff_1.en: Thank you so much! Hope to see you again!
